result.markdown:
--- # Document Metadata title: Example Document Template shorttitle: Template Guide # Used for running headers/footers shortauthors: Author et al. # Short author list for headers # Author Information authors: - name: Primary Author affiliations: - Department Name - Institution Name - name: Second Author orcid: 0000-0000-0000-0000 # Optional ORCID corresponding: true # Marks corresponding author email: author@institution.edu affiliations: - Department Name - Institution Name # Document Properties keywords: - Keyword One - Keyword Two - Keyword Three # Abstract Configuration abstract-title: "Summary:" # Custom abstract header abstract: | This template demonstrates the capabilities of Quarto for academic writing. It shows how to create complex documents with figures, tables, citations, and specialized formatting. The template supports multiple output formats including HTML, Word, and PDF via Typst. # Publication Information date: 2024-12-20 number-sections: true # Enable section numbering section-numbering: 1.1.1 # Numbering format bibliography: references.bib # Bibliography file citation: title: Full Document Title for Citations type: report # Publication type container-title: Series or Journal Name issued: last-modified doi: 10.0000/zenodo.0000000 --- # Key findings - This template demonstrates effective academic document structure. Key findings should summarize main points in clear, concise language. Each bullet point should be substantive and typically 2-3 sentences long. - Complex features can be demonstrated throughout, such as cross-references (see @fig-example), citations [@capitals_coalition_2024], and footnotes[^1]. These features work across all output formats including HTML, Word and PDF. - Multi-level bullets work as follows: - Sub-points should provide supporting detail - They can include citations [@tnfd_2024] - Second-level points with spacing between them are also possible: - Third level bullets demonstrate deeper hierarchy - With multiple points as needed [^1]: Footnotes can be placed inline or collected at the end. ![Example figure showing conceptual relationships. Place figures in the media/ folder.](media/picture%201.png){#fig-example} # Introduction {#sec-introduction} 1. This template uses numbered paragraphs for the main sections. Paragraphs should be concise and focused on a single main point or idea. Citations can be included [@gri2021; @tnfd_2024] and will be rendered according to the specified citation style. 2. Images can be included as either figures with captions (as above) or inline. Code blocks and other technical content can be included: ```python def example_function(): """Demonstrates code inclusion.""" return "Hello world" ``` 3. Tables can be included in several ways. Here's an R-generated table: ::: {#tbl-example .cell tbl-cap='Example table showing data organization'} ```{.r .cell-code .hidden} data <- data.frame( Category = c("A", "B", "C"), Value = c(10, 20, 30), Description = c("First", "Second", "Third") ) library(knitr) kable(data, format = "simple", align = 'l') ``` ::: {.cell-output-display} Category Value Description --------- ------ ------------ A 10 First B 20 Second C 30 Third ::: ::: # Advanced Document Features ## Complex Tables and Formatting {#sec-tables} 1. Complex tables can include multiple header levels, custom formatting, and footnotes. Here's an example using the `kable` function with custom CSS: ::: {.cell} ```{.css .cell-code .hidden} .small .table {font-size: 11px;} ``` ::: ::: small ::: {#tbl-complex .cell tbl-cap='Demonstration of Complex Table Formatting'} ```{.r .cell-code .hidden} complex_data <- data.frame( Category = c("Type A", "Type B", "Type C"), Description = c("Complex description with details", "Another detailed description", "Third detailed element"), Value1 = c(10.5, 20.3, 15.7), Value2 = c(45.2, 33.1, 28.9), Notes = c("Special case*", "Standard", "Modified†") ) kable(complex_data, format = "simple", booktabs = TRUE, align = 'l') ``` ::: {.cell-output-display} Category Description Value1 Value2 Notes --------- --------------------------------- ------- ------- -------------- Type A Complex description with details 10.5 45.2 Special case* Type B Another detailed description 20.3 33.1 Standard Type C Third detailed element 15.7 28.9 Modified† ::: ::: ::: * Indicates special condition † Modified calculation applied ## Callout Boxes and Special Content {#sec-callouts} 1. Callout boxes can highlight important information: ::: {.callout-note} ## Important Note Title This is an example note callout. It can contain: - Bullet points - *Formatted text* - Even `code snippets` ::: ::: {.callout-warning} ## Caution Warning callouts use different styling and icons. ::: ::: {.callout-tip} ## Suggestion Tips use a different style and icon. ::: ## Multi-Panel Figures {#sec-figures} 1. Complex figures can combine multiple panels with individual captions: ::: {#fig-panels .cell layout-ncol="2"} ```{.r .cell-code .hidden} # Example plot 1 plot(1:10, main="Panel A") # Example plot 2 plot(10:1, main="Panel B") ``` ::: {.cell-output-display} ![Panel A shows first element](index_files/figure-html/fig-panels-1.png){#fig-panels-1 width=672} ::: ::: {.cell-output-display} ![Panel B shows second element](index_files/figure-html/fig-panels-2.png){#fig-panels-2 width=672} ::: Multi-panel figure demonstration ::: ## Advanced Cross-Referencing {#sec-cross-ref} 1. Cross-references can be used for various elements: - Figures: See @fig-panels for a multi-panel example - Tables: As shown in @tbl-complex - Equations: Reference equation @eq-example below - Sections: Refer to earlier section on tables (#sec-tables) 2. Mathematical equations can be numbered and referenced: $$ \begin{equation} f(x) = ax^2 + bx + c \end{equation} $$ {#eq-example} 3. Inline mathematics can use single dollar signs: $E = mc^2$ ## Document Infrastructure {#sec-infrastructure} 1. This template supports: - Automatic table of contents generation - List of figures and tables - Custom header and footer content - Bibliography management - Multiple citation styles [@gri2021; @tnfd_2024] 2. Example of a complex citation block: ::: {.callout-note} ## Citation Example According to @capitals_coalition_2024 [p. 23], this specific method has several advantages. Multiple citations can be combined [@tnfd_2024; @tcfd_2024], and page numbers can be included [@gri2021, pp. 15-17]. ::: ## Interactive Elements {#sec-interactive} 1. When outputting to HTML, interactive elements can be included: ::: {#cell-fig-interactive .cell} ```{.r .cell-code .hidden} if (knitr::is_html_output()) { # Example interactive plot library(plotly) plot_ly(data = data.frame(x = 1:10, y = 1:10), x = ~x, y = ~y, type = 'scatter', mode = 'lines+markers') } ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stderr .hidden} ``` Loading required package: ggplot2 ``` ::: ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stderr .hidden} ``` Attaching package: 'plotly' ``` ::: ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stderr .hidden} ``` The following object is masked from 'package:ggplot2': last_plot ``` ::: ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stderr .hidden} ``` The following object is masked from 'package:stats': filter ``` ::: ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stderr .hidden} ``` The following object is masked from 'package:graphics': layout ``` ::: ::: {#fig-interactive .cell-output-display} ```{=html}
``` Interactive plot example (HTML only) ::: ::: ## Appendix {#sec-appendix} Additional tables and supplementary information can be included here. The template supports multiple appendices and complex table layouts: ::: small ::: {#tbl-appendix .cell tbl-cap='Example Appendix Table'} ```{.r .cell-code .hidden} appendix_data <- data.frame( Category = c("Type 1", "Type 2", "Type 3"), Description = c("Detailed example text", "More example content", "Final example entry"), Value = c("High", "Medium", "Low") ) kable(appendix_data, format = "simple", booktabs = TRUE, align = 'l') ``` ::: {.cell-output-display} Category Description Value --------- ---------------------- ------- Type 1 Detailed example text High Type 2 More example content Medium Type 3 Final example entry Low ::: ::: ::: # Appendix {.unnumbered} Note that references need to be included in BibTex format in the relevant file (references.bib) ::: {#refs} :::
